security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only documentation and workflow guidance. No executable code, no file system access beyond reading the skill file, no network calls, and no command execution capabilities. The skill provides Git best practices through markdown documentation.

content.user_title: Automate Git Branch and Commit Workflows
content.value_statement: Managing Git workflows manually leads to inconsistent commits and branch strategies. This skill provides automated guidance for branch creation, conventional commit messages, and pull request preparation across your codebase.
actual_capabilities: Validate branch naming conventions against type prefixes
Prepare conventional commit messages with semantic versioning
Generate pull request descriptions from commits
Check repository status and branch health
Map commit types to version impacts
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly
Cannot access remote repositories without explicit user action
No merge or rebase operations performed automatically

use_cases.title: Enforce commit standards
use_cases.description: Teams maintain consistent commit messages and branch naming across all contributors with automated validation.

use_cases.title: Streamline PR reviews
use_cases.description: Generate comprehensive pull request descriptions automatically from commit history and change tracking.

use_cases.title: Learn Git workflows
use_cases.description: New developers learn proper Git practices through interactive guidance and real-time feedback on their workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Create feature branch
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a branch for a new feature about user authentication

prompt_templates.title: Prepare commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Prepare a conventional commit message for adding user login functionality

prompt_templates.title: Review PR
prompt_templates.prompt: Check my pull request for authentication feature against best practices

prompt_templates.title: Generate PR description
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a pull request description from my recent commits on the auth feature

output_examples.input: Help me create a branch for adding user profile settings
output: âœ“ Next steps: git checkout -b feat/add-user-profile-settings

best_practices: Use semantic branch prefixes (feat/, fix/, docs/) to indicate change type automatically
Keep commits atomic and descriptive for easier changelog generation
Validate pull requests against checklists before requesting reviews
Maintain separate branches for each feature or fix to enable independent releases
anti_patterns: Working directly on main branch without feature branches
Using generic commit messages like 'fixed stuff' or 'update'
Skipping pull request checks and checklists before merging
Merging without reviewing the semantic version impact

faq.question: Does this skill run git commands automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance and templates but requires you to execute git commands manually for safety.

faq.question: Which git hosting platforms are supported?
faq.answer: All platforms including GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and Azure DevOps work with this workflow skill.

faq.question: What conventional commit formats are supported?
faq.answer: Standard format: type(scope): description. Supports feat, fix, docs, refactor, perf, test, chore, and hotfix.

faq.question: Is my repository data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a read-only guidance skill that does not access or modify your repository without explicit user action.

faq.question: Why is my branch being flagged as invalid?
faq.answer: Branches must follow the pattern type/descriptive-slug. Common issues include missing slash, uppercase letters, or wrong type prefix.

faq.question: How is this different from git CLI commands?
faq.answer: The CLI executes commands. This skill provides intelligent guidance, validation, and templates to improve your Git workflow quality.
